nodes.text: The pervasive use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technology substitutions and produces artifactually increasing carbon prices, undermining IAM policy relevance
IAMs are widely used to link long-term climate and economic dynamics and derive carbon price trajectories to guide policy
Existing external criticisms of IAMs include sensitive discount rate choice, arbitrary climate damage functions, and poor handling of catastrophic outcomes
CES functions were originally intended for capital-labor substitution with bounded substitution ranges and a constant elasticity parameter
Applying CES to technical factor inputs where full substitution is possible creates share-preserving, exponentially increasing substitution requirements as replacement progresses
IAM architectures typically assume exogenous economic growth and use monetized GDP-based damage functions, contributing to wide variation and potential bias in marginal carbon price outputs

Mathematically, the CES marginal rate of technical substitution depends on factor ratios and for nonzero rho requires exponentially more of the substitute input as substitution proceeds, yielding a declining ease of substitution

A stylized CES example replacing fossil energy (F) with renewable energy (R) shows: large initial fossil share needs many times more R to reduce F, substitution saturates far from complete, and required carbon price increases exponentially as substitution proceeds
Several mainstream IAMs and hybrid models that use CES or nested CES (e.g., GTEM-C, EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) reproduce exponentially rising carbon price trajectories and limited substitution of renewables

The CES-driven artifact of monotonically increasing carbon prices produces policy-relevant distortions: price diversion (focus on prices instead of physical planning), sticker shock (perceived infeasible costs), and technological myopia (preference for technologies already in model shares)

Technology myopia in CES-based IAM outputs favors incumbent or already-modeled options (nuclear, CCS, biomass) because CES makes adding non-shared substitutes prohibitively costly, biasing recommended mixes

Historical technological and energy transitions follow S-curve diffusion with dynamically changing elasticity and associated exponential deployment and cost declines, contradicting CES constant-elasticity behavior

Modifying models to use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (decreasing rho over time) can reproduce S-curve transitions and bounded carbon price trajectories consistent with empirical diffusion and falling substitute costs
Recommendation: adopt dynamic-elasticity CES modifications or shift to physics-based energy models and explicit deployment/phase-out targets rather than relying solely on rising carbon price signals

Limitations and assumptions include IAM reliance on GDP as proxy for welfare, uncertain climate sensitivity and damage extrapolations, and political choice embedded in discount rate selection which remain external sources of indeterminacy
